name: Femoral head blood supply by age
text: Femoral head blood supply changes with age. From birth to 4 years, supply comes from medial and lateral circumflex femoral arteries with additional contribution from the ligamentum teres. From age 4 years to adulthood, the dominant supply is via retinacular vessels from the medial femoral circumflex artery, with minimal contribution from the ligamentum teres. In adults, the medial femoral circumflex artery—via the lateral epiphyseal artery—is the primary blood supply to the femoral head.

name: Femoral head blood supply (birth to 4 years)
text: From birth to 4 years of age, the femoral head is supplied primarily by the medial and lateral circumflex femoral arteries, with additional contribution from the ligamentum teres via branches of the obturator artery.

name: Femoral head blood supply (4 years to adult)
text: From approximately 4 years of age through adulthood, the dominant blood supply to the femoral head is provided by posterosuperior and posteroinferior retinacular vessels arising from the medial femoral circumflex artery, with negligible contribution from the lateral circumflex femoral artery and minimal contribution from the ligamentum teres.

name: Femoral head blood supply (adult)
text: In adults, the medial femoral circumflex artery—through its lateral epiphyseal branch—provides the primary and critical blood supply to the femoral head.
